Message.Title: Sean Hannity’s Breathtaking Hypocrisy on NSA Surveillance ( same as with many on this board)
Message.Msg: (prism 2007 was to protect Americans they said, but prism in 2009 is unconstitutional well why didn't they say so in 2001 or 2005 or 2007?) Sean Hannity’s Breathtaking Hypocrisy on NSA Surveillance How does Sean Hannity feel about the federal government collecting information on millions of Americans? Well, that depends. According to clips compiled by Media Matters, the Fox News host’s position regarding government surveillance is evidently based entirely on who happens to be occupying the Oval Office at the time. For example, Hannity called the recent revelation about the extent of National Security Agency surveillance programs under Democratic President Barack Obama a “very clear violation of the Fourth Amendment.” But when President George W. Bush was in power, the conservative commentator seemed to have no problem with the NSA gathering data on Americans. In fact, he was a staunch defender of the practice during the Dubya years.

Topic.Title: NEARLY HALF OF ALL AMERICANS SAY SURVEILLANCE ARE ACCEPTABLE WITHIN LIMITS

Message.Msg: It is good it is getting exposure sooner or later. I guess with Bush the "Patriot Act" was the least of America's problems, as that bunch was hell-bend on destroying the country any way they could, so in that respect, just by the fact it is getting exposure now - it indicates America is much better off under Obama than it was under Bush. I just find it interesting that the conservatives are up in arms about the second amendment being sacred, but don't care about the 4th at all... Seems to me amendments are all about ensuring individual "rights and freedoms"..... so why 1 and 2 are "oh so important" and nobody can even name 3 and 4? OK - so 3rd is kinda lame if you look at it, but still..... 5th is well exposed as all the wall-street crooks, politicians, criminals and Hollywood use it all the time, but seriously, second and fourth should come hand in hand.

Topic.Title: NEARLY HALF OF ALL AMERICANS SAY SURVEILLANCE ARE ACCEPTABLE WITHIN LIMITS

Message.Msg: so far.... you meant to say "I have not seen or heard of any illegal use so far"..... And frankly - since the Patriot act makes practically ANY surveillance activity "LEGAL", so yeah- you may not ever hear of "illegal use" .... The point of the issue is not if it IS misused - it's if it the government CAN misuse it... and in this one, it's a loud and strong "YES, WE CAN" No checks or balances usually lead to abuse. Be it in corporate , criminal, or political world....... (hell - these 3 go hand in hand anyway...)

Message.Title: 57% fear the obvious
Message.Msg: That is a pretty big majority of folks that don't trust the government...can't blame them after the IRS behavior. 57% Fear Government Will Use NSA Data to Harass Political Opponents Friday, June 14, 2013 There is little public support for the sweeping and unaccountable nature of the National Security Agency surveillance program along with concerns about how the data will be used. Fifty-seven percent (57%) of voters nationwide believe it is likely the NSA data will be used by other government agencies to harass political opponents. A new Rasmussen Reports national telephone survey shows that just 30% consider it unlikely and 14% are not sure.

Message.Title: Ariz Gov Wins BIG for Obama !
Message.Msg: Arizona will expand Medicaid to cover nearly 300,000 poor residents next year after a bipartisan coalition passed a measure backed by Gov. Jan Brewer (R) through the state legislature on Thursday. Brewer, a conservative and avowed foe of President Barack Obama's health care reform law, announced her support for the Medicaid expansion in January, but faced stiff resistance from fellow Republicans in Arizona's House and Senate. During a marathon session that began Wednesday afternoon and stretched into the wee hours of Thursday morning before culminating in a final vote late Thursday afternoon, a handful of Republicans joined Democrats in the House and Senate to pass the Medicaid expansion. Although Obama's health care law continues to divide elected officials and the public along starkly partisan lines, Brewer is one of nine Republican governors who have bucked their party and embraced the Medicaid expansion.................... Pubs are falling in line to kiss Obama's bottom.
